About the Design Trust

The Design Trust for Public Space is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to improving public space in New York City.

Read our mission statement.

Board of Directors

Members of the design, financial, media, architectural and philanthropic communities sit on our board of directors.

Staff

Meet our dedicated staff.

Supporters

Our work is supported by firms, foundations, and individuals. View our most recent annual report (PDF).

Public space is...

Watch our video about the value of public space or download our "Public space is..." pamphlet (PDF).




Who We Are

We are urban visionaries, who think systemically about how cities work. From parks, plazas and streets to city buildings, transportation systems and entire neighborhoods, the Design Trust has been at the forefront of shaping New York City's public realm since 1995.
What We Do

We do research, design, and planning projects that positively impact every New Yorker's day-to-day quality of life. These projects are initiated by community groups, city agencies, and nonprofit organizations who look to the Design Trust's long experience engaging multiple stakeholders and deep familiarity with how New York City really works to influence city policy or design practice, improving the built environment.








How We Work

We believe that public/private partnerships are the most effective way to advance the quality of our public realm. Our unconventional project teams bring together city agencies, community groups, and private-sector experts to galvanize change in the way New York City's public spaces are designed, managed, or used.

2011 Design Trust for Public Space, 40 Worth Street, Suite 603, New York NY 10013  212.695.2432   info@designtrust.org

PROJECTS

The Design Trust takes on research, design and planning projects brought to us by community groups, public agencies and other nonprofit organizations. With our project partners, we then guide and manage the project to have the greatest impact on New York City's public realm.

For every project we aim to:
  1) build consensus among key stakeholders
  2) enlist New York's top private-sector talent
  3) engage a diverse audience
  4) deliver the vision and tools for long-term success

Design Trust projects result in publications, websites, exhibitions, and symposia intended to influence design practice or public policy. In the broadest sense, our projects generate a positive shift in the way the city's public spaces are created, managed, and used.



2011 Photo Urbanism:
From Roof to Table
Creating a comprehensive photo essay of all forms of urban agricultural activity across the five boroughs
Making Midtown
Generating a roadmap to support fashion design and manufacturing, and guide future development in the Garment District
Five Borough Farm
Developing strategies, evaluation tools and policies to support urban agricultural activity on a citywide scale
Photo Urbanism: Same Time Every Day (2009-11)
Revealed moments of grace by documenting five distinct locations at the same time, every day
High Performance Landscape Guidelines (2008-11)
Created a set of sustainable guidelines for New York City's 29,000 acres of parkland
Made in Midtown (2009-10)
Created an open-ended, independent study of the value of the Garment District to the fashion industry and to the city as a whole
2011 Photo Urbanism
Creating a comprehensive photo essay of all forms of urban agricultural activity across the five boroughs

Making Midtown | Generating a roadmap to support fashion design and manufacturing, and guide future development in the Garment District

Five Borough Farm

Park Design for the 21st Century (2008-11) | Creating a set of sustainable guidelines for New York City's 29,000 acres of parkland

Made in Midtown (2009-10)
Created an open-ended, independent study of the value of the Garment District to the fashion industry and to the city as a whole

Intersections: Grand Concourse Beyond 100 (2008-10) | Envisioned the future of the Bronx and its grandest boulevard

Reinventing Grand Army Plaza (2008-10) | Generated new visions to transform this majestic Brooklyn crossroads

Photo Urbanism 4: Out My Window (2007-08) | Depicted the evolving New York City landscape from the windows of private homes

Taxi 07 (2006-10) | Activated innovation in New York City's taxi system through a large-scale public exhibition and a 10-year strategic plan
Photo Urbanism 3: Jamaica Bay (2006-7) | Documented the communities and natural beauty of Jamaica Bay

Designing the Taxi (2005-6)
Rethought New York City's moveable public space on the eve of its centennial

Sustainable New York City (2005-6) | Made the case for environmental sustainability in everyday municipal operations

Photo Urbanism 2: The Bridge Project (2004) | Documented the impact of bridges on neighborhood life

Greening Infrastructure in the Public Right-of-Way (2003-6)
Set new standards for environmental responsibility in street construction

Long Island City: Connecting the Arts (2003-6) | Created an identity for a vibrant arts and industrial community

Times Square: Streetscape Improvement (2003-4) | Made the "crossroads of the world" pedestrian-friendly

Photo Urbanism 1: The Edge of New York (2002-3) | Archived the transforming waterfront

Reconstruction Report (2002)
Captured a public record of the lower Manhattan rebuilding effort

Thresholds of Eibs Pond Park 2 (2002) | Created a prototype for ecological restoration through park design

Reclaiming the High Line (1999-2002) | Produced the feasibility study that jumpstarted the High Line's conversion from derelict railway to open space

Thresholds of Eibs Pond Park 1 (2001) | Engaged the community in ecological restoration

Achieving a Balance: Housing and Open Space in Bronx Community Board 3 (1999-2000) | Met the parallel needs for housing and open space in the Bronx

Hell's Kitchen South: Developing Strategies (1999-2002) | Envisioned community-based development for Manhattan's Far West Side

Implementing the High Performance Building Guidelines (1999-2002) Analyzed New York City's green building efforts

Intermodal Transfer at East 125th Street (1999)
Imagined better transit connections for Harlem

High Performance Building Guidelines  (1998-9) | Set the standard for environmental responsibility in the public realm

Designing for Children in Community Gardens  (1997)
Tested remarkable ideas for innovative play spaces

Uneasy Spaces: A Photo Survey of Security in the Public Realm  (1997) | Examined security in the public realm through photography

Designing for Security: Design Guidelines for the Art Commission of New York City (1997-2002) | Investigated how public art and smart design can enhance public safety

Diego Beekman Houses Design Workshop: Improving the Quality of Life through Design (1996) | Recommended solutions for community-based public housing in the Bronx

Brooklyn Public Library Design Guidelines (1995-6) | Outlined innovative design principles for Brooklyn's new and historic libraries

PUBLICATIONS

Design Trust projects often culminate in a publication of guidelines, recommendations, or findings from our projects. These publications are produced by the Design Trust and available for a nominal fee that helps offset printing costs.

Book Orders

Many of our publications can be ordered from Amazon.com. Others are out-of-print and only available as a digital download. Details can be found on each publication page.

Questions?
Call 212-695-2432 x13 or send an email to orders@designtrust.org.

Record Crowds Celebrate Design Trust's Role in Transforming the High Line

An enthusiastic crowd demonstrated their tremendous support for the work of the Design Trust on Wednesday, Nov. 2 at the Art+Design Benefit Auction. Special guests Joshua David and Robert Hammond from Friends of the High Line gave the toast of the evening, saying that "the High Line wouldn't exist today if it wasn't for the Design Trust." We (heart) our beloved community of event leaders, sponsors, artists and designers who made our 2011 Benefit such a rocking party and a resounding success!

Look at the official party photos or check out the action from the photo booth!
Design Trust Announces Partnership with Nissan Americas for Taxi of TomorrowRecognizing the Design Trust's pioneering role to bring innovation to the NYC taxicab and system, Nissan Americas has engaged the Design Trust as an advisor for the Taxi of Tomorrow project.

Read more in the official press release (PDF).

FELLOWSHIPS
After the Design Trust selects a project, we work with our partners to determine what private-sector expertise is required for the project. We then award fellowships to the qualified professionals. This page includes a complete list of our current and past fellowship recipients.

The Fellowship Award

Design Trust fellows are offered a lead role on projects designed to have a real impact on New York City. Past fellowship stipends have averaged between $5,000 to $15,000 and, in most cases, an opportunity to publish project findings.

Applying for a Fellowship

There is no standing application procedure for a Design Trust fellowship, as the type of expertise needed varies from project to project. We encourage interested parties to sign up for our monthly e-newsletter, where all fellowship calls will be announced.

Meet Rob Stephenson

Rob was recently awarded the 2011 Photo Urbanism fellowship for his project, From Roof to Table: New York City's Growing Movement.

Read more about Rob>>

PARTNERS


The Design Trust does not undertake a project unless the city agency or community group best situated to implement the designs and plans we develop is involved from the very beginning. If you represent a public or non-profit organization, we can help turn your complex urban-design issues into a manageable project, then connect you with top-notch professionals our fellows who can generate solutions.

Project Selection Process


Projects are selected every 18-24 months through an open call for proposals. Generally, a proposal outlines a design or research project that requires activities or resources beyond the scope of the partner's budget, expertise, or institutional structure.

We work with prospective partners to hone their proposals, then submit the most promising to a jury for review. During each award cycle, the project jury selects one to three projects for Design Trust assistance.


City Government


By partnering with municipal agencies, we ensure that our projects address the tricky political and logistical issues that often keep good design intentions on the drawing board.

EVENTS
Design Trust events include public programs, tours, and exhibits attended by New Yorkers interested in the design of the city's public spaces.

Our Annual Benefit


The Design Trust's annual benefit brings together New York's leading urban innovators and thinkers for a dynamic evening of conversation, cocktails and community. The Benefit is the Design Trust's principal fundraiser 100% of the proceeds support our work to deliver design excellence to New York's public realm

2011 Benefit Art+Design Auction (Nov. 2, 2011)

Design Trust Council Events


The Design Trust Council is the intellectual and financial leadership circle of the Design Trust for Public Space. Specially designed social and educational events showcase cutting-edge projects with insight provided by visionaries whose work impacts our public built environment.

Mark your calendars! The 2011 Design Trust for Public Space Benefit Art+Design Auction will be on Wednesday, November 2nd at the gorgeous loft space at Center548 in Chelsea. Check out some photos from last year's fabulous event with honorary chair Tim Gunn.

Launched in 2006, the Design Trust Council is the intellectual and financial leadership group of the Design Trust for Public Space. Council membership demonstrates your commitment to the civic life of New York City and the public spaces where our shared experience unfolds.

Join today to receive members-only invitations to events spotlighting the leaders whose visionary ideas enliven our perspective and enrich our environment. Share your passion for the city, expand your professional and social networks, and be inspired to become a more active participant in the most diverse, dynamic urban culture the world has ever produced.
Membership Benefits
An investment in the Design Trust Council advances a more sustainable, accessible, vibrant New York.

Individual Membership $1,000
   One individual and one guest
Corporate Membership $2,500
   Three individuals and three guests
Lead Corporate Membership $5,000
   Eight individuals and eight guests

Membership benefits include:
   Invitations to the Design Trust Council annual event, designed exlusively for our members
   Access to lectures, launch parties and behind-the-scenes tours of New York's newest public spaces
   Discounted tickets to the Design Trust's Annual Benefit + Art Auction
   Advance distribution of all Design Trust publications
   Acknowledgment on the Design Trust website and annual report

Membership dues provide vital operating support for the Design Trust for Public Space and are 100% tax-deductible. To join, sign up using our secure online donation form or contact Kristin LaBuz at 212/ 695. 2432 x24 or klabuz@designtrust.org.

PRESS INFO

A small selection of recent and significant press coverage about the Design Trust can be found here, as well as press releases related to our projects, publications, exhibitions and public events. For additional press coverage about a specific project, publication, or event, please visit the page about that project, publication or event.

About the Design Trust

The Design Trust for Public Space is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization dedicated to improving public space in New York City.

Read our mission statement.

Board of Directors

Members of the design, financial, media, architectural and philanthropic communities sit on our board of directors.

Staff

Meet our dedicated staff.

Supporters

Our work is supported by firms, foundations, and individuals. View our most recent annual report (PDF).

Public space is...

Watch our video about the value of public space or download our "Public space is..." pamphlet (PDF).




Who We Are

We are urban visionaries, who think systemically about how cities work. From parks, plazas and streets to city buildings, transportation systems and entire neighborhoods, the Design Trust has been at the forefront of shaping New York City's public realm since 1995.
What We Do

We do research, design, and planning projects that positively impact every New Yorker's day-to-day quality of life. These projects are initiated by community groups, city agencies, and nonprofit organizations who look to the Design Trust's long experience engaging multiple stakeholders —and deep familiarity with how New York City really works— to influence city policy or design practice, improving the built environment.








How We Work

We believe that public/private partnerships are the most effective way to advance the quality of our public realm. Our unconventional project teams bring together city agencies, community groups, and private-sector experts to galvanize change in the way New York City's public spaces are designed, managed, or used.

© 2011 Design Trust for Public Space, 40 Worth Street, Suite 603, New York NY 10013  212.695.2432   info@designtrust.org

PROJECTS

The Design Trust takes on research, design and planning projects brought to us by community groups, public agencies and other nonprofit organizations. With our project partners, we then guide and manage the project to have the greatest impact on New York City's public realm.

For every project we aim to:
  1) build consensus among key stakeholders
  2) enlist New York's top private-sector talent
  3) engage a diverse audience
  4) deliver the vision and tools for long-term success

Design Trust projects result in publications, websites, exhibitions, and symposia intended to influence design practice or public policy. In the broadest sense, our projects generate a positive shift in the way the city's public spaces are created, managed, and used.

PUBLICATIONS

Design Trust projects often culminate in a publication of guidelines, recommendations, or findings from our projects. These publications are produced by the Design Trust and available for a nominal fee that helps offset printing costs.

Book Orders

Many of our publications can be ordered from Amazon.com. Others are out-of-print and only available as a digital download. Details can be found on each publication page.

Record Crowds Celebrate Design Trust's Role in Transforming the High Line

An enthusiastic crowd demonstrated their tremendous support for the work of the Design Trust on Wednesday, Nov. 2 at the Art+Design Benefit Auction. Special guests Joshua David and Robert Hammond from Friends of the High Line gave the toast of the evening, saying that "the High Line wouldn't exist today if it wasn't for the Design Trust." We (heart) our beloved community of event leaders, sponsors, artists and designers who made our 2011 Benefit such a rocking party and a resounding success!

Look at the official party photos or check out the action from the photo booth!
Design Trust Announces Partnership with Nissan Americas for Taxi of TomorrowRecognizing the Design Trust's pioneering role to bring innovation to the NYC taxicab and system, Nissan Americas has engaged the Design Trust as an advisor for the Taxi of Tomorrow project.

FELLOWSHIPS
After the Design Trust selects a project, we work with our partners to determine what private-sector expertise is required for the project. We then award fellowships to the qualified professionals. This page includes a complete list of our current and past fellowship recipients.

The Fellowship Award

Design Trust fellows are offered a lead role on projects designed to have a real impact on New York City. Past fellowship stipends have averaged between $5,000 to $15,000 and, in most cases, an opportunity to publish project findings.

Applying for a Fellowship

There is no standing application procedure for a Design Trust fellowship, as the type of expertise needed varies from project to project. We encourage interested parties to sign up for our monthly e-newsletter, where all fellowship calls will be announced.

Meet Rob Stephenson

Rob was recently awarded the 2011 Photo Urbanism fellowship for his project, From Roof to Table: New York City's Growing Movement.

Read more about Rob>>

PARTNERS


The Design Trust does not undertake a project unless the city agency or community group best situated to implement the designs and plans we develop is involved from the very beginning. If you represent a public or non-profit organization, we can help turn your complex urban-design issues into a manageable project, then connect you with top-notch professionals – our fellows – who can generate solutions.

Project Selection Process


Projects are selected every 18-24 months through an open call for proposals. Generally, a proposal outlines a design or research project that requires activities or resources beyond the scope of the partner's budget, expertise, or institutional structure.

We work with prospective partners to hone their proposals, then submit the most promising to a jury for review. During each award cycle, the project jury selects one to three projects for Design Trust assistance.


City Government


By partnering with municipal agencies, we ensure that our projects address the tricky political and logistical issues that often keep good design intentions on the drawing board.

EVENTS
Design Trust events include public programs, tours, and exhibits attended by New Yorkers interested in the design of the city's public spaces.

Our Annual Benefit


The Design Trust's annual benefit brings together New York's leading urban innovators and thinkers for a dynamic evening of conversation, cocktails and community. The Benefit is the Design Trust's principal fundraiser — 100% of the proceeds support our work to deliver design excellence to New York's public realm

Launched in 2006, the Design Trust Council is the intellectual and financial leadership group of the Design Trust for Public Space. Council membership demonstrates your commitment to the civic life of New York City and the public spaces where our shared experience unfolds.

Join today to receive members-only invitations to events spotlighting the leaders whose visionary ideas enliven our perspective and enrich our environment. Share your passion for the city, expand your professional and social networks, and be inspired to become a more active participant in the most diverse, dynamic urban culture the world has ever produced.
Membership Benefits
An investment in the Design Trust Council advances a more sustainable, accessible, vibrant New York.

Individual Membership — $1,000
  • One individual and one guest
Corporate Membership — $2,500
  • Three individuals and three guests
Lead Corporate Membership — $5,000
  • Eight individuals and eight guests

Membership benefits include:
  • Invitations to the Design Trust Council annual event, designed exlusively for our members
  • Access to lectures, launch parties and behind-the-scenes tours of New York's newest public spaces
  • Discounted tickets to the Design Trust's Annual Benefit + Art Auction
  • Advance distribution of all Design Trust publications
  • Acknowledgment on the Design Trust website and annual report

Membership dues provide vital operating support for the Design Trust for Public Space and are 100% tax-deductible. To join, sign up using our secure online donation form or contact Kristin LaBuz at 212/ 695. 2432 x24 or klabuz@designtrust.org.

PRESS INFO
A small selection of recent and significant press coverage about the Design Trust can be found here, as well as press releases related to our projects, publications, exhibitions and public events. For additional press coverage about a specific project, publication, or event, please visit the page about that project, publication or event.
